abstract: Wells Fargo plays it close to the vest. "Our ability to grow revenue and earnings will suffer if we are unable to sell more products," the bank disclosed to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Theo Francis at Morningstar's footnoted.com recently observed that, for anyone who knows what a bank does, the disclosure would likely illicit a "Duh." The S.E.C. called the disclosure "too vague to be meaningful to investors." Wells Fargo has since revised its filing.

The S.E.C. called the disclosure "too vague to be meaningful to investors." Wells Fargo has since revised its filing. Read more »

headline.main: S.E.C. Scolds Wells Fargo For 'Vague' Disclosure
